   Assessment and Plan
   ASSESSMENT AND PLAN: Mr. [**Known lastname **] is a 58-year-old man with history of
   congenital heart disease and repairs in [**2160**], [**2185**] and [**2199**], status
   post replacements of the pulmonic and mitral valves with mosaic
   bioprostheses, closure of VSD and PFO, and surgical repair of the
   tricuspid valve, with CHF, DM, chronic afib on coumadin and multiple
   GIB, on home O2 transferred from OSH for continued management of heart
   failure.
   .
   # Hypercarbic Resp failure: Patient has baseline hypercarbia with PCO2
   in 60s and baseline bicarb in 40s. On O2 at home for presumed pulmonary
   hypertension.  Etiology for initial acute hypercarbic resp failure
   unclear but possible hypoventilated [**1-5**] CHF exacerbation or oxygen
   narcosis. PE also could present similarly but patient was therapeutic
   on coumadin to OSH. No report of ingestions. Hypoxia improved with
   ventilation. Gases improved to baseline. No known lung parenchymal
   disease.
   - consider PA catheter/Right heart cath in am
   - wean vent as tolerated
   - PE is felt unlikely at this time; will defer CTA
   - f/u TTE results
   - f/u TSH
   .
   # Hypotension: Unclear etiology. Sv02 on admission 92 but unclear how
   to interpret given strong possibility of VSD/PFO.  Also CVP measured at
   16 but given TR may not accurately reflect volume status/preload. No
   lactate to indicated hypoperfusion. Maybe be hypovolemic [**1-5**]
   overdiuresis or hemotypsis. No WBC or fever to indicate underlying
   infection/septic shock. Certainly, cardiogenic shock is possible but
   need more data prior to definitely diagnosis.
   - wean levophed/dopamine as tolerated
   - additional fluid bolus will be given as patient appears clinically
   dry
   - defer swan-ganz placement for now
   - hold antibiotics as no evidences of infection but follow up blood
   cultures
   - trend hct as below
   .
   # Hemoptysis: Patient noted to have grossly bloody material from ET
   tube upon admission which had been going on at OSH. Unclear if
   traumatic intubation with coumadin on board. NG lavage negative upon
   arrival. Prelim CXR unchanged. The differential includes
   PNA/bronchitis, bronchiectasis, pulm AVM, or cancer.
   - f/u final CXR
   - f/u sputum Cx and gram stain
   - consult pulmonary in am
   - non-contrast chest CT
   - hold anticoagulation
   - maintain active T+S
   - trend hct q8h, xfuse hct<21 or active ischemia
   .
   # PUMP: Patient with history of pulmonary hypertension and borderline
   RV failure presented with hypotension and OSH echo showed elevated PA
   consistent with worsened RV failure. Given history of congenital heart
   disease etiology of RV failure most likely [**1-5**] pulmonary hypertension.
   His pulmonary hypertension is likely [**1-5**] to worsening VSD or mitral
   regurgitation. Alternatively, his worsening RV function can also be due
   to worsen tricuspid regurgitation. No ischemic EKG changes to positive
   troponins to indicate RV infarct. Bedside echo obtained upon arrival to
   [**Hospital1 54**] but difficult to interpret with but estimated EF 30-40%. An
   infective endocarditis could also account for valvular deterioration.
   - eventually may proceed to RHC
   - f/u TTE
   - cont dopamine and levophed to titrate MAP>60
   - appreciate cardiothoracic surgery input re: valve integrity
   - hold diureses
   - would benefit from beta blocker once hemodynamically stable
   .
   # CORONARIES: No history of CAD on cath [**12-11**]. Cardiogenic shock
   unlikely [**1-5**] to ischemia.
   - f/u EKG
   - f/u cardiac enzymes
   - d/c ASA
   - continue statin
   .
   # RHYTHM: History of Chronic Afib present on admission, anticoagulated
   on admission, held for hemoptysis and rate controlled.
   - monitor on tele
   - monitor coags
   - resume anticoagulation once hemoptysis improves
   .
   # AOCKD: Baseline Cr unknown as last documented Cr here when patient
   was acutely ill. Cr now 1.8.  Urine lytes consistent with pre-renal
   etiology.
   - trend Cr, avoid nephrotoxins if possible
   - improved on fluids last night, will continue to bolus
   .
   # Hyponatremia: Clinically, dry mucous membranes. Likely [**1-5**]
   hypovolemia in setting of recent diureses of 5-7L at OSH.
   - 1L NS bolus
   - trend serum lytes
   - hold diuresis
   - f/u TSH
   .
   # Eosinophilia: Absolute with diffuse erythematous rash c/w drug
   eruption. Patient received Vanc/Cef/Clindamycin at OSH for unclear
   reasons but were stopped which are most likely culprits for drug rate.
   - trend eos
   - monitor for now
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia: Resolved at OSH, not on heparin so HIT unlikely. No
   oozing from PIV.
   - f/u DIC labs
   - trend plts
   - xfuse plt<10 or <50k if bleeding
   .
   # Anemia: Patient has a history of anemia, unclear baseline hct, also
   currently bleeding.
   - guaiac stools
   - f/u iron studies
   - trend hct q8h, xfuse hct<21 or active ischemia
   .
   # Diabetes: Apparently diet controlled.
   - follow QID FS with HISS
   - f/u HgbA1c
   .
   # HL: cont lipitor
   .
   # Depression/Anxiety: cont abilify
   .
   FEN: follow and replete lytes, nutrition consult for tube feeding
   .
   ACCESS: L subclavian, R radial aline
   .
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with subQ hep
   -Pain management with fentanyl
   -Bowel regimen with senna/colace
   -VAP bundle
   -Stress ulcer ppx: q24h PPI
   .
   CODE: full code (per OSH documentation)-need confirmation
   .
   COMM: Proxy name: [**First Name8 (NamePattern2) 3676**] [**Known lastname **]  Relationship: brother  Phone:
   [**Telephone/Fax (1) 10805**]
   .
   Nutrition: tube feed consult
   .
   DISPO: CCU for now
   ICU Care

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old man with a history of congenital heart disease and multiple repairs, including replacements of the pulmonic and mitral valves, closure of VSD and PFO, and surgical repair of the tricuspid valve. The patient is currently experiencing several medical complications that require attention:

1. Hypercarbic respiratory failure: The patient has baseline hypercarbia with PCO2 in the 60s and a baseline bicarb in the 40s. This condition could be due to hypoventilation caused by CHF exacerbation, oxygen narcosis, or pulmonary embolism. Further evaluation is needed to determine the exact cause.

2. Hypotension: The etiology of the patient's hypotension is unclear. The SvO2 on admission was 92%, but it is difficult to interpret due to the possibility of VSD/PFO. The CVP measured at 16, but given TR (tricuspid regurgitation), it may not accurately reflect the volume status or preload. No lactate levels were mentioned to indicate hypoperfusion. Possible causes include hypovolemia, overdiuresis, or hemoptysis.

3. Hemoptysis: The patient has grossly bloody material from the ET tube upon admission, which had been ongoing at OSH. It is unclear if this is due to traumatic intubation or coumadin use. Preliminary chest X-ray is unchanged. The

Based on the provided information, the patient is a 58-year-old man with a history of congenital heart disease and multiple surgeries to repair the heart valves. He has been admitted to the ICU for management of heart failure. The patient's current medical conditions include hypercarbic respiratory failure, hypotension, hemoptysis, pump failure, coronary artery disease, atrial fibrillation, acute kidney injury, hyponatremia, eosinophilia, thrombocytopenia, anemia, diabetes, depression/anxiety, and depression.

The patient's vital signs are as follows:
- Temperature: 36.6°C
- Heart rate: 96 bpm
- Blood pressure: 111/56 mmHg
- Respiratory rate: 20 breaths per minute
- Oxygen saturation: 99%
- Heart rhythm: Atrial fibrillation
- Central venous pressure: 14 mmHg

The patient has been placed on several medications, including dopamine, norepinephrine, midazolam (versed), fentanyl, and others. He is also receiving infusions of dopamine and norepinephrine.

The patient's lab results show:
- White blood cell count: 8.6
- Hemoglobin: 10.7 g/dL
- Sodium: 142 mEq/L
- Potassium: 4.3 mEq/L
- Glucose: 125 mg/dL

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old man with a history of congenital heart disease and repairs, status post replacements of the pulmonic and mitral valves with mosaic bioprostheses, closure of VSD and PFO, and surgical repair of the tricuspid valve. He has a history of CHF, DM, chronic afib on coumadin, and multiple GIB. The patient was transferred from OSH for continued management of heart failure.

The patient presented with hypercarbic respiratory failure, hypotension, hemoptysis, and signs of right ventricular failure. The assessment and plan section outlines several potential medical complications that could arise:

1. Hypercarbic respiratory failure: The patient has a baseline hypercarbia with PCO2 in the 60s and baseline bicarb in the 40s. The etiology for the initial acute hypercarbic respiratory failure is unclear, but possible causes include a CHF exacerbation or oxygen narcosis. No report of ingestions. Hypoxia improved with ventilation. Gases improved to baseline. No known lung parenchymal disease.
   - Consider PA catheter/Right heart cath in am
   - Wean vent as tolerated
   - Consider CTA chest in am
   - f/u TSH

2. Hypotension: The etiology of hypotension is unclear. SvO2 on admission was 92%, but the interpretation is uncertain

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of congenital heart disease and multiple surgeries, including valve replacements and closure of VSD and PFO. He has chronic atrial fibrillation and is on coumadin. He presents with hypercarbic respiratory failure, hypotension, hemoptysis, and possible pneumonia caused by MRSA. He also has a history of pulmonary hypertension, worsening right ventricular (RV) failure, and tricuspid regurgitation. Other issues include acute renal failure, hyponatremia, eosinophilia, thrombocytopenia, anemia, diabetes, depression/anxiety, and liver problems. The patient is currently in the ICU and requires close monitoring and management.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypercarbic respiratory failure: The patient has baseline hypercarbia, which needs to be managed with appropriate ventilatory support.
2. Hypotension: The cause of hypotension is unclear, but possible causes include hypovolemia, overdiuresis, or hemoptysis. Close monitoring and fluid management are necessary.
3. Hemoptysis: The patient has grossly bloody material from the endotracheal tube, which may be due to traumatic intubation or coumadin use. Further investigation is required to determine the cause.
4. MRSA pneumonia: The patient has MRSA in the sputum culture, and appropriate antibiotic therapy needs to be continued for the required duration

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of congenital heart disease and multiple surgeries, including valve replacements and closure of VSD and PFO. He has chronic atrial fibrillation and is on coumadin. The patient was admitted for management of heart failure and is currently in the ICU. He presented with hypercarbic respiratory failure, hypotension, hemoptysis, and worsening right ventricular failure. 

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure: The patient has a history of chronic respiratory acidosis with compensation. His current condition of hypercarbic respiratory failure may be due to hypoventilation, possibly exacerbated by CHF exacerbation or oxygen narcosis. Further investigation is needed to determine the exact cause.

2. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension could be due to several factors, including hypovolemia from overdiuresis, hemoptysis, or cardiogenic shock. Additional data is required to confirm the diagnosis.

3. Hemoptysis: The patient has grossly bloody material from the ET tube upon admission. This could be due to traumatic intubation or a underlying condition such as pneumonia, bronchiectasis, pulmonary arteriovenous malformation (PAVM), or cancer. Further evaluation is necessary to determine the cause.

4. Right Ventricular Failure: The patient's worsening right ventricular failure may be caused by pulmonary hypertension, worsening VSD, mitral regurgitation

Summary:
The patient is a 58-year-old man with a history of congenital heart disease and multiple surgeries for valve replacements and closure of defects. He is currently in the ICU due to multiple complications. 

Summary of Progress Notes:
- The patient appears dry, so fluids are given. Bronchoscopy will be done tomorrow morning.
- Sputum culture grows MRSA, and the patient must be on vancomycin or linezolid for 3 weeks. He is already started on vancomycin.
- The patient failed a pulmonary function test trial, showing severe restrictive ventilatory impairment with chronic respiratory acidosis.
- A central line is placed, and the subclavian line is pulled.
- The patient's tachycardia improves after giving 3 liters of normal saline, and urine output and pressor requirements decrease.
- The patient has allergies to Aldactone and an unknown medication causing gynecomastia.
- The patient has a history of chronic atrial fibrillation and is on Coumadin.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of congenital heart disease and multiple surgical repairs. He presents with hypotension, respiratory failure, hemoptysis, and a history of chronic atrial fibrillation. The patient has severe pulmonary hypertension, moderate to severe tricuspid regurgitation, and a history of diabetes and depression. He is currently intubated and on mechanical ventilation.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypercarbic respiratory failure: The patient's baseline hypercarbia with PCO2 in the 60s and bicarb in the 40s may lead to further respiratory failure if not managed appropriately.
2. Hypotension: The unclear etiology of the patient's hypotension requires further evaluation and management to maintain adequate blood pressure.
3. Hemoptysis: The presence of grossly bloody material from the endotracheal tube suggests possible causes such as pneumonia/bronchitis, bronchiectasis, pulmonary arteriovenous malformation, or cancer. Further investigation is needed to determine the underlying cause.
4. Right ventricular failure: The patient's history of pulmonary hypertension and worsening right ventricular function may result in right ventricular failure if not properly managed.
5. Thrombocytopenia: The resolved thrombocytopenia requires monitoring and further investigation to determine the cause.
6. Anemia: The patient's history of anemia needs to be addressed and managed appropriately.
7. Diabetes: The patient's diabetes should be closely monitored and managed with appropriate medication and lifestyle modifications.
8. Depression/Anxiety: The patient's mental health conditions should be addressed and managed with appropriate medication and counseling.

Note: This summary and potential medical complications are based on the information provided in the physician's daily progress note.

Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of congenital heart disease and subsequent surgical repairs, including replacements of the pulmonic and mitral valves, closure of VSD and PFO, and surgical repair of the tricuspid valve. The patient has a background of CHF, DM, chronic AFib, and multiple GIB. He was transferred from OSH for continued management of heart failure.

The patient presented with hypotension, hypoxia, and hypercarbic respiratory failure. The initial acute hypercarbic respiratory failure etiology is unclear, but it could be due to CHF exacerbation, oxygen narcosis, or pulmonary embolism. The patient's SvO2 on admission was 92%, but the interpretation is unclear due to the possibility of VSD/PFO. The CVP measured at 16, but it may not accurately reflect the volume status/preload due to tricuspid regurgitation.

The patient also had grossly bloody material from the ET tube upon admission, which had been ongoing at OSH. This could be due to traumatic intubation or coumadin therapy. The preliminary CXR was unchanged, and further evaluation is needed to determine the cause, such as PNA/bronchitis, bronchiectasis, pulmonary arteriovenous malformation, or cancer.

The patient's baseline Cr was unknown, but the current Cr is 1.8, and the urine lytes

   reserve of this patient. Pneumonia may also coexist in this atelectatic
   lung. Right pulmonary artery dilatation compresses mainstem bronchi
   particulary on the right which may also contribute to the limtied
   reserve. Pattern of ground glass nodulrity can be seen in primary
   pulmonary hypertension. Spiculated nodule in the left upper lobe.
   Recommend followup chest CT in three months.

Summary:
The patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of congenital heart disease and multiple repairs, including replacements of the pulmonic and mitral valves, closure of VSD and PFO, and surgical repair of the tricuspid valve. He has chronic atrial fibrillation, congestive heart failure, diabetes mellitus, chronic gastrointestinal bleeding, and depression/anxiety. The patient presented with hypotension, hypoxia, hypercarbic respiratory failure, hemoptysis, and renal failure. He was found to have MRSA pneumonia and required intubation and mechanical ventilation. 

The patient's current medications include pantoprazole (Protonix), heparin sodium (prophylaxis), and fentanyl. He is also receiving nutrition through tube feeding. The patient's vital signs show a temperature of 37.8°C (100.1°F), heart rate of 75 bpm, blood pressure of 88/38 mmHg (81/49 mmHg), respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute, oxygen saturation of 99%, and a central venous pressure of 7 mmHg. 

The patient's laboratory results indicate elevated white blood cell count, hemoglobin, and platelet count, but decreased hematocrit, creatinine, potassium, and sodium levels. His blood gases show a pH of 7.34, PaO2/FiO2 ratio of 246, and bicarbonate level of 32 mEq/L. The patient's ECG shows atrial fibrillation, and the chest X-ray is unremarkable. 

The patient's assessment and plan include multiple medical complications such as hypercarbic respiratory failure, hypotension, MRSA pneumonia, hemoptysis, acute renal failure, hyponatremia, eosinophilia, thrombocytopenia, anemia, depression/anxiety, and diabetes mellitus. 

Potential medical complications that can arise include worsening of the patient's heart failure, development of further lung infections, persistent renal failure, electrolyte imbalances, bleeding complications due to thrombocytopenia, and potential worsening of the patient's mental health status.

Summary:
Based on the provided medical progress note, the patient has a history of congenital heart disease and has undergone multiple surgeries to repair various heart defects. The patient is currently in the ICU for management of heart failure and is on home oxygen due to pulmonary hypertension. 

The patient's current conditions and potential medical complications include:

1. Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure: The patient has baseline hypercarbia with elevated PCO2 levels in the 60s and a history of COPD. The etiology of the initial acute hypercarbic respiratory failure is unclear, but it is most likely due to pneumonia (PNA) in the setting of COPD. There is no report of aspiration, and hypoxia improved with ventilation. The patient's gases improved to baseline, and no known lung parenchymal disease was identified. 

2. Hypotension: The cause of the patient's hypotension is unclear. SvO2 on admission was 92%, but it is unclear how to interpret this due to the possibility of VSD/PFO. CVP measured at 16 but may not accurately reflect volume status/preload due to tricuspid regurgitation. No lactate is present to indicate hypoperfusion. The patient may be hypovolemic from overdiuresis or hemoptysis. No white blood cell count or fever is present to indicate underlying infection/septic shock. Cardiogenic shock is also possible but requires more data before a definitive diagnosis.

   unclear but most [**Name (NI) 10842**] PNA.  No report of aspiration. Hypoxia

   - Bronch c/w PNA
   - sent for cultures and on vanc and cefepime, on albuterol and
   ipratropium.
   - wean vent as tolerated.  Patient is hypercarbic at baseline but
   appears to be hyperventilating at this time (alkalemic on last ABG with
   pCO2=43).  Will increase FiO2 in case oxygen drive is causing
   hyperventilation.
   .
   # Hypotension: Could be [**1-5**] hypovolemia +/- distributive shock.  CVP
   measured at 16 but given TR may not accurately reflect volume
   status/preload.  No lactate to indicated hypoperfusion.  Patient has
   been repleted 5L since admission with substantial decrease in pressor
   requirement, as well as resolution of pre-renal insufficiency.
   - wean levophed/dopamine as tolerated
   - goal I+O even, if patient hypotensive will consider addl fluid bolus

   - trend hct
   .

   - vancomycin for 3 weeks (started [**10-14**]), added cefepime per bronch

   tube upon admission which had been going on at OSH. Unclear if

   arrival. Prelim CXR unchanged. The differential includes

Summary:
Summary:
- The patient is a 58-year-old man with a history of congenital heart disease and multiple surgical repairs.
- He has been admitted to the ICU for management of heart failure, chronic atrial fibrillation, and multiple infections.
- The patient is currently on mechanical ventilation with pressure support, but has tolerated a FiO2 of 35% and is being weaned off assisted ventilation.
- His vital signs include a temperature of 37.8°C (100.1°F), heart rate of 80 bpm, blood pressure of 125/46 mmHg, respiratory rate of 25 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%.
- The patient's review of systems is unchanged from admission, except for gross hemoptysis upon admission.
- Laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, hemoglobin, and troponin T levels.
- The patient has several medical complications including hypercarbic respiratory failure, hypotension, MRSA pneumonia, hemoptysis, pulmonary hypertension, and thrombocytopenia.
- He is currently receiving various medications including antibiotics, sedation, and pressor support.
- The patient's care plan includes weaning off the ventilator, managing his blood pressure and fluid status, treating MRSA pneumonia, investigating the cause of hemoptysis, and addressing other medical issues such as eosinophilia, thrombocytopenia, anemia, diabetes, and thrush.

Potential medical complications that can arise:
1. Worsening respiratory failure: The patient's baseline hypercarbia and the need for mechanical ventilation indicate a risk of worsening respiratory failure. Close monitoring of oxygenation and ventilation parameters is necessary.
2. Hemodynamic instability: The patient's hypotension and dependence on vasopressor support suggest a potential risk of hemodynamic instability. Frequent assessment of blood pressure and heart rate is required, along with careful management of fluid and medication administration.
3. Infection: The patient has already been diagnosed with MRSA pneumonia and may be at risk for additional infections due to his immunocompromised state and invasive lines. Regular assessment of vital signs, chest x-rays, and laboratory parameters is necessary to detect any new infections promptly.
4. Bleeding: The patient's history of hemoptysis and ongoing bloody secretions from the endotracheal tube pose a risk of bleeding. Close monitoring for signs of bleeding and appropriate management, including holding anticoagulation, are essential.
5. Pulmonary hypertension: The patient's history of pulmonary hypertension and evidence of right ventricular dysfunction indicate a risk of further deterioration. Continuous monitoring of cardiac function and appropriate management, including inotropic support and diuresis, are important.
6. Thrombocytopenia: The patient's low platelet count may increase the risk of bleeding. Regular monitoring of platelet counts and careful management of anticoagulation and invasive procedures are necessary.

Overall, the patient's complex medical history and current medical complications require close monitoring and multidisciplinary care to manage his acute issues and prevent potential complications.

He is receiving mechanical ventilation and has shown improvement in his gases. Bronchoscopy revealed bronchitis consistent with PNA, and cultures are pending. He is being treated with vancomycin and cefepime.

2. Hypotension: The patient is experiencing hypotension, which may be due to hypovolemia or distributive shock. 3. MRSA Pneumonia: The patient has MRSA in his sputum culture, and his sputum culture here also grew coagulase-positive Staphylococcus. He is being treated with vancomycin for three weeks and has been added on cefepime based on bronchoscopic

3. MRSA Pneumonia: The patient has an infection caused by methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA), which may require extended treatment with appropriate antibiotics.

5. Hemoptysis: The patient has experienced grossly bloody material from the endotracheal tube, which could be due to trauma during intubation or bleeding related to coagulopathy.

6. Right Ventricular Failure: The patient's history of pulmonary hypertension and congenital heart disease suggests that right ventricular failure may be worsening. This could be caused by pulmonary hypertension, valvular issues, or infective endocarditis.

Summary:
Summary:
The patient is a 58-year-old man with a history of congenital heart disease and multiple surgeries to repair his heart valves. He has a background of congestive heart failure, diabetes, chronic atrial fibrillation, and gastrointestinal bleeding. The patient was admitted to the ICU for management of heart failure and was placed on mechanical ventilation due to respiratory failure. He has been on pressors for hypotension, but these have been gradually reduced as his condition improved. The patient has been diagnosed with MRSA pneumonia and is being treated with vancomycin and cefepime. He also has anemia, thrombocytopenia, eosinophilia, and a diffuse erythematous rash, which is suspected to be a drug eruption. The patient's renal function and electrolytes are being monitored closely.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypercarbic respiratory failure: The patient has a baseline hypercarbia, and it is essential to continue monitoring his respiratory status and adjusting ventilator settings accordingly.
2. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may be due to hypovolemia or distributive shock. Continuous monitoring of blood pressure and appropriate fluid management are necessary. The use of pressors may be required if hypotension persists.
3. MRSA pneumonia: The patient has been diagnosed with MRSA pneumonia, and his treatment regimen includes vancomycin and cefepime. It is crucial to monitor his response to antibiotics and ensure adequate source

Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 58-year-old man with a history of congenital heart disease and multiple surgical repairs. He was admitted for continued management of heart failure. The patient has been experiencing respiratory failure, hypotension, MRSA pneumonia, acute anemia, hemoptysis, right ventricular failure, chronic atrial fibrillation, eosinophilia, thrombocytopenia, anemia, diabetes, thrush, depression/anxiety, and hypercarbic respiratory failure.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure: The patient has a baseline hypercarbia with elevated PCO2 levels in the 60s and a baseline bicarb in the 40s. This indicates difficulty in eliminating carbon dioxide from the body, which can lead to respiratory failure if not managed properly.

2. Hypotension: The patient is experiencing low blood pressure, which may be due to hypovolemia or distributive shock. This can compromise organ perfusion and lead to tissue hypoxia and organ dysfunction.

3. MRSA Pneumonia: The patient has been diagnosed with MRSA pneumonia, which is a type of bacterial infection caused by methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus. If left untreated, it can worsen the respiratory failure and cause sepsis.

4. Acute Anemia: The patient has experienced a sudden drop in hemoglobin levels, indicating acute anemia. This can result in inadequate oxygen delivery

The patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of congenital heart disease and multiple surgeries, including replacements of the pulmonic and mitral valves, closure of VSD and PFO, and surgical repair of the tricuspid valve. He presents with hypercarbic respiratory failure, hypotension, MRSA pneumonia, acute Hct drop, hemoptysis, and evidence of right ventricular (RV) failure.

1. Hypercarbic respiratory failure: The patient has baseline hypercarbia with a PCO2 in the 60s and bicarb in the 40s. This condition may progress if not properly managed.

   Assessment and Plan
   58-year-old man with history of congenital heart disease and repairs in
   [**2160**], [**2185**] and [**2199**], status post replacements of the pulmonic and
   mitral valves with mosaic bioprostheses, closure of VSD and PFO, and
   surgical repair of the tricuspid valve, with CHF, DM, chronic afib on
   coumadin and multiple GIB, on home O2 transferred from OSH for
   continued management of heart failure.
   .
   # Hypercarbic Resp failure: Patient has baseline hypercarbia with PCO2
   in 60s and baseline bicarb in 40s. On O2 at home for presumed pulmonary
   hypertension.  Etiology for initial acute hypercarbic resp failure
   unclear but most [**Name (NI) 10842**] PNA.  No report of aspiration. Hypoxia
   improved with ventilation. Gases improved to baseline. No known lung
   parenchymal disease.  Sputum cx here (+) for MRSA.
   - Bronch c/w PNA.
   - sent for cultures and on vanc and cefepime, on albuterol and
   ipratropium.
   - as patient is tolerating PS, will consider extubation today.
   - wean vent as tolerated.  Patient is hypercarbic at baseline.
   .
   # Hypotension: Could be [**1-5**] hypovolemia +/- distributive shock.  CVP
   measured at 16 but given TR may not accurately reflect volume
   status/preload.  No lactate to indicated hypoperfusion.  Patient has
   been repleted 5L since admission with substantial decrease in pressor
   requirement, as well as resolution of pre-renal insufficiency.
   - now off pressors
   - goal I+O even, if patient hypotensive will consider addl fluid bolus
   (i/o slightly positive)
   - trend hct
   .
   # MRSA PNA
 found to have MRSA in sputum cx at OSH.  Sputum cx here
   grew out coag + Staph, [**Last Name (un) **] pending.
   - vancomycin for 3 weeks (started [**10-14**]), added cefepime per bronch
   recs.  No indications for atypical coverage at this time.
   - f/u vanc level
 ok to give today
   # acute Hct drop
 downtrending since admission.  No clear source of
   bleeding as hemoptysis has resolved.
   - transfuse 1u pRBC
   - check hemolysis labs, B12, folate
   # hemoptysis: Patient noted to have grossly bloody material from ET
   tube upon admission which had been going on at OSH. Unclear if
   traumatic intubation with coumadin on board. NG lavage negative upon
   arrival. Prelim CXR unchanged. The differential includes
   PNA/bronchitis, bronchiectasis, pulm AVM, or cancer.  No continued
   bloody secretions from ET tube.
   - bronch showed only intubation trauma
   - suction / oral care as needed
   .
   # PUMP: Patient with history of pulmonary hypertension and borderline
   RV failure presented with hypotension and OSH echo showed elevated PA
   consistent with worsened RV failure. Given history of congenital heart
   disease etiology of RV failure most likely [**1-5**] pulmonary hypertension.
   His pulmonary hypertension is likely [**1-5**] to worsening VSD or mitral
   regurgitation. Alternatively, his worsening RV function can also be due
   to worsen tricuspid regurgitation. No ischemic EKG changes to positive
   troponins to indicate RV infarct. Bedside echo obtained upon arrival to
   [**Hospital1 54**] but difficult to interpret with but estimated EF 30-40%. An
   infective endocarditis could also account for valvular deterioration.
   - cont dopamine and levophed to titrate MAP>60
   - hold diuresis
   - would benefit from beta blocker once hemodynamically stable
   .
   # RHYTHM: History of Chronic Afib present on admission, anticoagulated
   on admission, held for hemoptysis and rate controlled.
   - monitor on tele
   - monitor coags
   - resume anticoagulation once hemoptysis improves
   .
   # Eosinophilia: Absolute with diffuse erythematous rash c/w drug
   eruption. Patient received Vanc/CTX/Clindamycin at OSH for unclear
   reasons but were stopped which are most likely culprits for drug rate.
   - resolving now off CTX/clindamycin
   .
   # Thrombocytopenia: Resolved at OSH, not on heparin so HIT unlikely. No
   oozing from PIV.
   - significantly improved since admission; ?drug rxn from abx
   .
   # Anemia: Patient has a history of anemia, unclear baseline hct, also
   currently bleeding.
   - guaiac stools
   - f/u iron studies
   - trend hct q8h, xfuse hct<21 or active ischemia
   .
   # Diabetes: Apparently diet controlled.
   - follow QID FS with HISS
   - f/u HgbA1c
   .
   # thrush
 noted to have thrush in mouth, on nystatin oral swishes.
   .
   # HL: cont lipitor
   .
   # Depression/Anxiety: cont abilify
   .
   FEN: follow and replete lytes, nutrition consult for tube feeding
   .
   ACCESS: L subclavian, R radial aline
   .
   PROPHYLAXIS:
   -DVT ppx with subQ hep
   -Pain management with fentanyl
   -Bowel regimen with senna/colace
   -VAP bundle
   -Stress ulcer ppx: q24h PPI
   .

Based on the information provided in the progress note, there are several potential medical complications that can arise:

1. Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure: The patient has baseline hypercarbia with increased levels of carbon dioxide (PCO2) in their blood. This condition can lead to respiratory failure if not properly managed.

2. Hypotension: The patient is experiencing low blood pressure, which may be due to hypovolemia or distributive shock. It is important to monitor the patient's vital signs and consider fluid resuscitation if necessary.

3. MRSA Pneumonia: The patient has been diagnosed with MRSA pneumonia, which requires appropriate antibiotic treatment. This can be a serious complication if not promptly addressed.

4. Acute Hct Drop: The patient has experienced a sudden drop in hematocrit levels, indicating possible bleeding or hemolysis. Further investigation and monitoring are needed to determine the cause and appropriate management.

5. Hemoptysis: The patient has grossly bloody material from the endotracheal tube, which could be due to traumatic intubation or an underlying lung condition. It is important to evaluate and manage this symptom to prevent further complications.

6. Right Ventricular Failure: The patient has a history of pulmonary hypertension and borderline right ventricular (RV) failure. Worsening RV failure can occur due to various factors such as pulmonary hypertension, valvular deterioration, or infective endocarditis. Summary:
The patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of congenital heart disease and surgical repairs, chronic atrial fibrillation, and multiple comorbidities including congestive heart failure, diabetes mellitus, and chronic kidney disease. He was admitted to the ICU due to acute hypercarbic respiratory failure, hypotension, and MRSA pneumonia. The patient has been on mechanical ventilation and has required multiple pressors for hemodynamic stability. He is currently off pressors and tolerating spontaneous breathing.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure: The patient has a baseline hypercarbia with elevated PCO2 levels in the 60s. It is important to closely monitor his respiratory status and adjust ventilation parameters as necessary.
2. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension may be due to hypovolemia, distributive shock, or cardiac dysfunction. Close monitoring of his blood pressure and fluid balance is essential. Additional diagnostic tests such as echocardiography may be required to evaluate cardiac function.
3. MRSA Pneumonia: The patient has an active MRSA infection in his sputum culture. Appropriate antibiotic therapy should be continued, and close monitoring of clinical response and culture results is necessary.
4. Thrombocytopenia: The patient has a history of thrombocytopenia, which has resolved since admission. Regular monitoring of platelet counts is important to detect any recurrence of low platelet

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old male with a complex medical history including congenital heart disease and subsequent repairs, chronic atrial fibrillation, diabetes mellitus, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). The patient was admitted to the ICU for management of heart failure and acute hypercarbic respiratory failure. 

The patient's current conditions include:
1. Hypercarbic respiratory failure: The patient has a baseline elevated carbon dioxide level and bicarbonate level. He is receiving oxygen therapy at home for presumed pulmonary hypertension. The etiology of the initial acute hypercarbic respiratory failure is unclear, but it is suspected to be due to a pulmonary infection. The patient is being treated with albuterol, ipratropium, vancomycin, and cefepime for MRSA pneumonia. He is currently tolerating pressure support and may be considered for extubation today.
2. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension could be due to hypovolemia or distributive shock. Central venous pressure (CVP) measurement shows 16, but it may not accurately reflect the patient's volume status or preload. The patient has been repleted with 5 liters of fluid since admission, resulting in a substantial decrease in pressor requirement and resolution of pre-renal insufficiency. The patient is now off pressors, and additional fluid bolus may be considered if the patient is hypotensive.

Summary:
- The patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of congenital heart disease and multiple surgeries to repair valves and close VSD and PFO.
- He has a background of CHF, DM, chronic AFib, and multiple gastrointestinal bleeding episodes.
- The patient is currently admitted to the ICU for management of heart failure and suspected pneumonia.
- His current vital signs include a temperature of 37.6°C, heart rate of 67 bpm, blood pressure of 108/53 mmHg, respiratory rate of 22 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 95% on supplemental oxygen.
- The patient is intubated and on SIMV mode ventilation with a tidal volume of 400 mL, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%.
- The patient has a central venous pressure (CVP) of 27 mmHg, with positive fluid balance since 12 AM.
- His blood glucose level is elevated at 152 mg/dL.
- Laboratory results show an elevated white blood cell count (WBC) of 266 K/uL, hemoglobin (Hb) of 7.8 g/dL, sodium (Na+) of 141 mEq/L, potassium (K+) of 5.4 mEq/L, and creatinine (Cr) of 1.3 mg/dL.
- The patient has been diagnosed with MRSA pneumonia and is receiving appropriate antibiotics.
- He has been weaned off pressors and has shown improvement in his condition.
- The patient's hemoptysis has resolved, but he still has an acute drop in Hct since admission, with no clear source of bleeding identified.
- He is at risk for hypercarbic respiratory failure due to his chronic AFib and previous episodes of hypercarbia.
- The patient's eosinophilia is likely due to a drug reaction.
- He has a history of thrombocytopenia but is now improving.
- The patient's anemia may be related to chronic blood loss.
- He requires ongoing management for his diabetes and depression/anxiety.
- The patient is scheduled for a tracheostomy and weaning off mechanical ventilation.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure: The patient has a history of chronic AFib and previous episodes of hypercarbia. This increases his risk for hypercarbic respiratory failure, especially if he becomes less compliant with his ventilation settings or if his pulmonary function deteriorates further.
2. Ventilator-Associated Pneumonia (VAP): Being intubated and on mechanical ventilation increases the risk of developing VAP. The patient's recent diagnosis of MRSA pneumonia suggests that he may be at higher risk for developing VAP.
3. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient has a history of multiple gastrointestinal bleeding episodes. Even though his hem

The patient has been repleted with 5 liters of fluid since admission, resulting in a substantial decrease in pressor requirements and resolution of pre-renal insufficiency. Summary:
The patient is a 58-year-old man with a history of congenital heart disease and subsequent repairs, as well as chronic atrial fibrillation on Coumadin. He was transferred to the ICU for management of heart failure. The patient has multiple comorbidities including diabetes, chronic atrial fibrillation, and a history of gastrointestinal bleeding. He is currently on home oxygen for presumed pulmonary hypertension.

The patient presented with hypercarbic respiratory failure, and his initial acute hypercarbic respiratory failure is unclear, but most likely due to a pneumonia (PNA). He is being treated with vancomycin and cefepime, along with albuterol and ipratropium. The patient has been weaned off pressors and is now hemodynamically stable.

The patient also has hypotension, which could be due to hypovolemia or distributive shock. His central venous pressure (CVP) is measured at 16, but given the tricuspid regurgitation, it may not accurately reflect his volume status or preload. The patient has been repleted with fluids since admission, resulting in a substantial decrease in pressor requirement and resolution of pre-renal insufficiency.

Furthermore, the patient has methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) pneumonia. He was started on vancomycin for three weeks, and cefepime was added per bronchoscopic recommendations. No indications for atypical coverage at this time

Summary:
The patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of congenital heart disease and multiple repairs, including replacements of the pulmonic and mitral valves, closure of VSD and PFO, and surgical repair of the tricuspid valve. He also has a history of CHF, DM, chronic AF on coumadin, and multiple GIB. The patient was transferred from OSH for continued management of heart failure.

The patient has been diagnosed with hypercarbic respiratory failure, hypotension, MRSA PNA, acute Hct drop, hemoptysis, PUMP (pulmonary hypertension and RV failure), rhythm (chronic AF), eosinophilia, thrombocytopenia, diabetes, thrush, and depression/anxiety. He is currently on various medications including Aldactone, Cefepime, Vancomycin, Pantoprazole, Fentanyl, Heparin Sodium, and Midazolam.

The patient's vital signs include a temperature of 37.7°C, heart rate of 65 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 100/45 mmHg to 126/64 mmHg, respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%. His CVP is 15 mmHg, and his fluid balance is positive with a total input of 958 mL and output of 717 mL.

The patient's laboratory results show a WBC count of 6.3 K/uL, Hct of 24.7%, Plt of 274 K/uL, Cr of 1.3 mg/dL, TCO2 of 30, Glucose of 152 mg/dL, and other lab values within normal ranges.

The patient's physical examination reveals intubation, responsive and interactive, with no appreciable rales. His heart rhythm is irregular, and he has 2+ pulses bilaterally. His abdomen is soft, non-tender, and nondistended. Other findings include a wound care note, a nutrition consult, and plans for tracheostomy rehabilitation and consolidation of outpatient medications.

Potential medical complications that can arise include worsening respiratory failure, persistent hypotension, ongoing MRSA infection, further drop in Hct, persistent hemoptysis, progression of pulmonary hypertension and right ventricular failure, continued arrhythmias, eosinophilia, thrombocytopenia, uncontrolled diabetes, thrush, and worsening depression/anxiety.

Summary:
Summary of Progress Note:
The patient is a 58-year-old man with a history of congenital heart disease and multiple surgical repairs. He has been admitted to the ICU for management of heart failure, chronic atrial fibrillation, and presumed pulmonary hypertension. His current medications include coumadin, albuterol, ipratropium, vancomycin, and cefepime.

Vital signs include a temperature of 37.7°C, heart rate of 65 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 100/45-126/64 mmHg, respiratory rate of 20 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 96%. The patient is intubated and receiving mechanical ventilation in SIMV/PSV mode.

The patient has a history of hypercarbic respiratory failure, hypotension, methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA) pneumonia, acute hematocrit drop, hemoptysis, and right ventricular (RV) failure. His current assessments and plans include:

1. Hypercarbic respiratory failure: The patient has a baseline hypercarbia with PCO2 in the 60s and baseline bicarb in the 40s. He is being managed with ventilation and daily spontaneous breathing trials.

2. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension could be due to hypovolemia or distributive shock. His central venous pressure (CVP) is measured at 16, but it may not accurately reflect volume status/preload. No lactate levels indicate hypoperfusion. The patient has been repleted with fluids, resulting in a substantial decrease in pressor requirement and resolution of pre-renal insufficiency.

3. MRSA Pneumonia: The patient has MRSA in his sputum culture. He is receiving vancomycin for 3 weeks and cefepime per bronchoscopic recommendations. Atypical coverage is not indicated at this time.

4. Acute hematocrit drop: The patient has experienced a downtrending hematocrit since admission. No clear source of bleeding has been identified, and his baseline hematocrit is unclear. He has been transfused with one unit of packed red blood cells (pRBCs), and further evaluation is needed.

5. Hemoptysis: The patient had grossly bloody material from the endotracheal (ET) tube upon admission. This may have been due to traumatic intubation or coumadin use. No continued bloody secretions from the ET tube have been observed.

6. Pulmonary hypertension and right ventricular failure: The patient presented with hypotension and an echocardiogram showing elevated pulmonary artery pressures consistent with worsened RV failure. His pulmonary hypertension is likely due to worsening valvular regurgitation or infective endocarditis.

7. Chronic atrial fibrillation: The patient's atrial fibrillation is rate-controlled and monitored closely. Anticoagulation is resumed once hem

The patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of congenital heart disease, including multiple surgeries and valve replacements. He has chronic atrial fibrillation and is on anticoagulation therapy. The patient was admitted to the ICU for management of heart failure, but upon arrival, he was found to have acute hypercarbic respiratory failure, likely due to an MRSA pneumonia. He required intubation and mechanical ventilation.

The patient's medical conditions include chronic heart failure, diabetes mellitus, and chronic atrial fibrillation. He also has a history of gastrointestinal bleeding and anemia. His current medications include albuterol, ipratropium, vancomycin, cefepime, fentanyl, pantoprazole, and heparin sodium.

Laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, slightly low hemoglobin levels, elevated liver enzymes, and abnormal coagulation profiles. Imaging studies reveal evidence of pulmonary hypertension and right ventricular dysfunction.

1. Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure: The patient presented with acute hypercarbic respiratory failure, likely secondary to MRSA pneumonia. He required intubation and mechanical ventilation for respiratory support.

Based on the provided progress note, there are several potential medical complications that can arise for the patient:

1. Hypercarbic respiratory failure: The patient has a history of chronic hypercarbia and is on home oxygen due to presumed pulmonary hypertension. The etiology of the initial acute hypercarbic respiratory failure is unclear, but it may be related to a previous pneumonia (PNA). The patient is currently being treated with ventilation and antibiotics for MRSA PNA.

2. Hypotension: The patient's hypotension could be due to hypovolemia or distributive shock. The central venous pressure (CVP) is measured at 16 but may not accurately reflect the volume status or preload due to tracheostomy. The patient has been repleted with fluids and has shown a substantial decrease in pressor requirement and resolution of pre-renal insufficiency.

3. MRSA PNA: The patient has an active MRSA infection in the sputum culture. He is being treated with vancomycin for three weeks and has also been started on cefepime per bronchial recommendations.

4. Acute Hct drop: The patient's hematocrit (Hct) level has been downtrending since admission. No clear source of bleeding has been identified, and hemolysis labs, B12, and folate levels are normal. The patient's baseline Hct is unclear.

5. Hemoptysis: The patient presented with grossly bloody material

Summary:
The patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of congenital heart disease and multiple surgeries to repair his heart valves. He has been admitted to the ICU for management of heart failure and chronic atrial fibrillation. The patient has several medical complications including hypercarbic respiratory failure, hypotension, MRSA pneumonia, acute hemolysis, hemoptysis, acute renal failure, pulmonary hypertension, and thrombocytopenia. 

The patient's hypercarbic respiratory failure is likely due to his underlying pulmonary hypertension and may be exacerbated by his recent MRSA pneumonia. His hypotension could be attributed to hypovolemia or distributive shock, but further evaluation is needed as the central venous pressure (CVP) measurements may not accurately reflect his volume status. 

The patient has been diagnosed with MRSA pneumonia, for which he is receiving vancomycin and cefepime. His acute hemolysis has resolved, but the cause remains unclear. The patient also experienced hemoptysis upon admission, which has since resolved. 

His acute renal failure is characterized by an elevated creatinine level, and further evaluation is needed to determine the cause. The patient's pulmonary hypertension may have worsened due to right ventricular failure, possibly as a result of his underlying congenital heart disease or infective endocarditis. 

The patient's chronic atrial fibrillation is well-documented, and he is currently anticoagulated. He also exhibits eosinophilia

Summary:
The patient is a 58-year-old man with a history of congenital heart disease and multiple repairs, including replacements of the pulmonic and mitral valves, closure of VSD and PFO, and surgical repair of the tricuspid valve. He also has CHF, DM, chronic afib, and multiple GIB. He is on home O2 and was transferred from OSH for continued management of heart failure.

The patient has several medical complications:

1. Hypercarbic respiratory failure: The patient has baseline hypercarbia with PCO2 in the 60s and baseline bicarb in the 40s. He is on O2 at home for presumed pulmonary hypertension. The etiology for initial acute hypercarbic respiratory failure is unclear, but most likely it is due to pneumonia (PNA). There are no reports of aspiration. Hypoxia improved with ventilation, and gases improved to baseline. No known lung parenchymal disease. Sputum culture here (+) for MRSA PNA. The patient is on vancomycin and cefepime, with daily rsbi and PSV wean trials.

2. Acute renal failure (ARF): The patient's Cr is elevated this AM at 1.5. The baseline Cr is unclear, with trough Cr during this hospitalization being 1.0. There is no acute elevation in BUN. It is likely pre-renal, and the patient will need to be rehydrated

Summary:
The patient is a 58-year-old man with a history of congenital heart disease and multiple repairs, including pulmonic and mitral valve replacements, closure of VSD and PFO, and surgical repair of the tricuspid valve. He presents with chronic atrial fibrillation, congestive heart failure (CHF), diabetes mellitus (DM), chronic kidney disease (CKD), and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD).

The patient was admitted to the ICU for acute hypercarbic respiratory failure, likely secondary to an acute pneumonia (PNA) with an identified MRSA infection. He was started on vancomycin and cefepime. The patient's initial hypoxia improved with ventilation, and his gases returned to baseline levels. No known lung parenchymal disease was noted.

The patient has a history of pulmonary hypertension and borderline right ventricular (RV) failure, which is likely contributing to his current presentation. His worsening RV function may be due to worsening VSD or mitral regurgitation, or possibly worsening tricuspid regurgitation. No evidence of an RV infarct was observed.

The patient's renal function has been impaired, with an elevated creatinine level of 1.5. This is likely pre-renal in origin, possibly due to hypovolemia or distributive shock. He has been repleted with 5 liters of fluids since admission, leading to a substantial decrease in pressor requirement and resolution of pre-

Summary:
The patient is a 58-year-old man with a history of congenital heart disease and multiple repairs, including valve replacements. He has a background of chronic atrial fibrillation, heart failure, diabetes mellitus, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. The patient was admitted for management of heart failure and respiratory failure. He presented with hypotension and acute hypercarbic respiratory failure, possibly due to pulmonary hypertension. The patient also had acute kidney injury, likely pre-renal, and was found to have MRSA pneumonia. He experienced hemoptysis and had a significant drop in hemoglobin, which was initially attributed to bleeding but later determined to be unrelated. The patient's condition improved with continued management, and he was weaned off pressors and ventilatory support.

2. Acute Kidney Injury: The patient exhibited signs of acute kidney injury, possibly pre-renal in nature. Rehydration and careful management of fluid balance are necessary to prevent further renal dysfunction.
3. MRSA Pneumonia: The patient was found to have MRSA pneumonia. It is crucial to continue appropriate antibiotic therapy and monitor for any signs of treatment failure or worsening infection.

Summary:
The patient is a 58-year-old man with a history of congenital heart disease and various surgical repairs. He is currently in the ICU for management of heart failure, chronic atrial fibrillation, and multiple gastrointestinal bleeding (GIB). He is on home oxygen due to presumed pulmonary hypertension. The patient was transferred from another hospital for continued management of his heart failure.

The patient has several medical complications that can arise:

1. Hypercarbic respiratory failure: The patient has baseline hypercarbia with a PCO2 in the 60s and a baseline bicarb in the 40s. He is on O2 at home for presumed pulmonary hypertension. The etiology of the initial acute hypercarbic respiratory failure is unclear, but most likely it is a pneumonia (PNA). There is no report of aspiration. Hypoxia improved with ventilation. Gases improved to baseline. No known lung parenchymal disease. Sputum culture grew MRSA, and the patient is currently on vancomycin and cefepime.

2. Acute kidney injury (ARF): The patient's creatinine is elevated this morning at 1.5. It is unclear what the baseline creatinine is; trough creatinine during this hospitalization is 1.0. There is no acute elevation in BUN. It is likely pre-renal, so the patient needs to be rehydrated.

3. MRSA pneumonia: The patient has MRSA in his sputum

Summary of Progress Note:
- The patient is a 58-year-old man with a history of congenital heart disease and multiple surgical repairs.
- He has been admitted to the ICU for management of heart failure, acute hypercarbic respiratory failure, and MRSA pneumonia.
- The patient is on mechanical ventilation and has shown improvement in oxygenation.
- His condition is complicated by acute kidney injury, hypotension, deep vein thrombosis in the upper extremity, hemoptysis, and anemia.
- He has a history of chronic atrial fibrillation and is on anticoagulation.
- The patient's medical history includes chronic hypertension, diabetes mellitus, hyperlipidemia, and depression/anxiety.
- He is currently receiving various medications, including anticoagulants, diuretics, beta-blockers, and antibiotics.
- The patient's current vital signs include a temperature of 37.7°C, heart rate of 70 bpm, blood pressure of 109/53 mmHg, respiratory rate of 17 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 94% on CPAP.
- Laboratory results show elevated white blood cell count, slightly low hemoglobin, and elevated creatinine levels.
- Imaging studies reveal evidence of pulmonary hypertension and right ventricular failure.
- The patient's medical team is monitoring his condition closely and has implemented appropriate interventions to manage his multiple complications.

Potential Medical Complications:

Summary:
Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 58-year-old male with a complex medical history including congenital heart disease, multiple surgeries, chronic atrial fibrillation, and diabetes. He was admitted to the ICU for management of heart failure and acute hypercarbic respiratory failure, which was likely due to a previous pneumonia (PNA) caused by methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA).

The patient has several ongoing medical issues and complications:

1. Acute kidney injury (ARF): His creatinine levels are elevated, and there is uncertainty about his baseline creatinine level. It is likely pre-renal in nature, and he needs to be rehydrated with intravenous fluids. Renal dosing for vancomycin should be adjusted accordingly.

2. Hypotension: The patient's blood pressure is low, which could be due to hypovolemia or distributive shock. His central venous pressure (CVP) is measured at 16 but may not accurately reflect his volume status or preload. He has been repleted with fluids, leading to a decrease in pressor requirement and resolution of pre-renal insufficiency.

3. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the upper extremity: The patient has swelling and edema in his left upper extremity, which is concerning for a possible DVT. An ultrasound of the affected limb should be considered, and anticoagulation with warfarin should be

The patient is a 58-year-old man with a history of congenital heart disease and multiple repairs, including replacements of the pulmonic and mitral valves, closure of VSD and PFO, and surgical repair of the tricuspid valve. He also has chronic atrial fibrillation and diabetes.

The patient was admitted to the ICU with hypercarbic respiratory failure due to presumed pulmonary hypertension. He was found to have MRSA pneumonia, for which he received vancomycin and cefepime. His current vital signs include a temperature of 37.7°C (99.8°F), heart rate of 70 bpm, blood pressure of 109/53 mmHg, respiratory rate of 17 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 94%. He is on CPAP/PSV ventilation mode with a tidal volume of 336 mL, positive end-expiratory pressure (PEEP) of 5 cmH2O, and fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%.

The patient has had several complications during his ICU stay. These include acute kidney injury (AKI) with an elevated creatinine level, hypotension possibly due to hypovolemia or distributive shock, deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in the left upper extremity, acute hemolysis, and hemoptysis. His hemoglobin concentration has also been dropping, which may be related to anemia or bleeding.

Summary: The patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of congenital heart disease and multiple surgeries for valve replacements, closure of VSD and PFO, and surgical repair of the tricuspid valve. He presents with chronic atrial fibrillation, congestive heart failure, diabetes mellitus, chronic kidney disease, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease. The patient was admitted to the ICU due to acute hypercarbic respiratory failure, possibly caused by methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus pneumonia (MRSA PNA). Other complications include acute kidney injury (ARF), hypotension, deep vein thrombosis in the upper extremity (DVT UE), anemia, hemoptysis, and right ventricular (RV) failure. The patient is currently receiving various medications, including vancomycin, cefepime, albuterol, ipratropium, fluconazole, warfarin, and beta blockers. He is also on a ventilator with CPAP/PSV mode, receiving supplemental oxygen. The patient's condition is being closely monitored, with frequent assessments of vital signs, laboratory values, and imaging studies.

The patient's medical history includes chronic atrial fibrillation, congestive heart failure (CHF), diabetes mellitus (DM), chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), and depression/anxiety.

The patient was admitted to the ICU for management of heart failure and was on home oxygen due to presumed pulmonary hypertension. The initial acute hypercarbic respiratory failure was attributed to MRSA pneumonia. The patient has since been treated with vancomycin and completed an 8-day course of cefepime.

The patient's renal function has shown an elevated creatinine level of 1.5, but this has resolved with fluids. There are no acute elevations in BUN, and the patient is likely experiencing pre-renal acute kidney injury (AKI). Fluid resuscitation and free water flushes with tube feeds have been initiated.

The patient also has a history of MRSA pneumonia, for which he has been receiving vancomycin for three weeks and previously completed a course of cefepime. No indications for atypical coverage are currently present.

Summary:
The patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of congenital heart disease, including repairs and replacements of valves, chronic atrial fibrillation, diabetes, and depression/anxiety. He is currently in the ICU for management of heart failure, acute hypercarbic respiratory failure, and MRSA pneumonia. The patient's medical conditions include hypotension, acute kidney injury, deep vein thrombosis in the upper extremity, hemoptysis, pulmonary hypertension, rhythm disturbances, eosinophilia, thrombocytopenia, and diabetes.

Potential Medical Complications:
1. Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure: The patient has baseline hypercarbia with an elevated PCO2 in the 60s and baseline bicarb in the 40s. This condition can lead to respiratory acidosis and may require further ventilation support.
2. Acute Kidney Injury: The patient's creatinine levels are elevated, indicating potential acute kidney injury. This condition can progress to chronic kidney disease if not managed appropriately.
3. Deep Vein Thrombosis (DVT): The patient has a history of DVT in the upper extremity, which increases the risk of clot formation and potential embolism to the lungs.
4. Hemoptysis: The patient has a history of grossly bloody material from the endotracheal tube, which may indicate bleeding in the respiratory tract. Further investigation is needed to identify the source of bleeding.
5. Pulmonary Hypertension

Summary of Progress Note:

The patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of congenital heart disease and multiple surgical repairs, including replacements of the pulmonic and mitral valves, closure of VSD and PFO, and surgical repair of the tricuspid valve. He has chronic atrial fibrillation on coumadin, chronic heart failure, diabetes mellitus, and chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD). The patient is currently in the ICU for continued management of heart failure.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Hypercarbic Respiratory Failure: The patient has baseline hypercarbia with increased PCO2 levels in the 60s and decreased bicarb levels in the 40s. He is on home oxygen for presumed pulmonary hypertension. Initially, the etiology for acute hypercarbic respiratory failure was MRSA pneumonia. His hypoxia has improved with ventilation, and sputum cultures and bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) have confirmed MRSA pneumonia. The patient is currently on vancomycin and has completed an 8-day course of cefepime.

2. Acute Kidney Injury (ARF): The patient's creatinine level is elevated at 1.5, but the baseline creatinine is unclear. Trough creatinine during hospitalization is 1.0. There is no acute elevation in BUN, and the kidney injury is likely pre-renal as it has resolved with fluid administration. The patient will receive

He is on home oxygen for presumed pulmonary hypertension. The patient has been diagnosed with MRSA pneumonia and has completed an 8-day course of cefepime. He is currently on vancomycin for 3 weeks.

Summary:
The patient is a 58-year-old male with a history of congenital heart disease and multiple surgeries for valve replacements and repairs. He is currently admitted to the ICU for management of heart failure and respiratory failure secondary to MRSA pneumonia. The patient has been on mechanical ventilation and has shown improvement in oxygenation.

The patient's medical conditions include chronic atrial fibrillation, diabetes mellitus, hypertension, chronic kidney disease, and anxiety/depression. He is on multiple medications including anticoagulants, diuretics, beta-blockers, statins, and psychiatric medications.

The patient's recent lab results show elevated white blood cell count, hemoglobin, and platelet count. His blood urea nitrogen (BUN) and creatinine levels are within normal limits. The electrolyte levels are also within normal limits.

The patient's vital signs are stable with a heart rate of 69-101 bpm, blood pressure ranging from 118/59-135/69 mmHg, respiratory rate of 14-24 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 97%. His temperature is slightly elevated at 37.8°C.

The patient's physical examination reveals a responsive and interactive patient with an irregular heartbeat. There are no appreciable rales or wheezes in the lungs, but there is evidence of bowel sounds. The patient has good pulses bilaterally, and there is no evidence of deep vein thrombosis (DVT) on ultrasound.
